inlineContent.text: In this chapter weâ€™ll finish implementing the applicationâ€™s core functionality by allowing the user to create Lean Coffee events and their topics.
Create a lightweight, reusable Form Submission Presenter to handle form validation before submitting data to the API

Weâ€™ve created 2 forms in this application so far, the Sign in and Sign up forms, and weâ€™re about to add 2 more. There are a couple of core behaviors of a form that I think can be easliy extracted in a new presenter. They are Validation and Submission. While this presenter wonâ€™t know how to handle the details of those things, it can provide a stable interface to the consuming views and establish a clear pattern throughout the application.
Go ahead and make a new file named
and add these 2 functions.
Then weâ€™ll include a third function. This is the function that will provide the stable interface to the views like I mentioned earlier. It does a few things:

1. It validates the form or throws an error (you can do throw instead of return false when you override this later) 2. It handles concurrency and error handling by calling the perform function 3. It handles form submission.
This will allow us to subclass this presenter and simply override the 2 internal functions to include form validation and do the work of submitting the data to the API.
Homework
Go ahead and use this presenter for Sign in and Sign up in place of the standard
and display meaningful errors to the user when the form is invalid.
In this section weâ€™ll add a
button to the Home view and the form needed to create a new Lean Coffee event
This time weâ€™ll start with the presenter. This presenter will submit data to the API to create a Lean Coffee. According to the
all we really need to send is a title. So weâ€™ll add the encodable model here while weâ€™re at it.
Then weâ€™ll make sure we inherit from the new FormSubmissionPresenter and begin to override the functions. For now, weâ€™ll override the form submission to make the call to the api.

And weâ€™ll add some really simple form validation to make sure that there is some text present before we submit the form. You can add whatever validation here youâ€™d prefer, even throw custom errors for you to display to the user if youâ€™d like to.
Next, weâ€™ll create the view for this form. Weâ€™ll start with a stack and a title.
Then the text field and the button.
And to acutally make the request, weâ€™ll pass in the presenter.
If you test this out, youâ€™ll realize quickly that you donâ€™t know if it finished the job or not. Letâ€™s fix that.
What weâ€™ll do here is inject the presentation mode of the view. After the presenter finishes its work weâ€™ll dismiss the view by â€œrecievingâ€ an event from the Presenterâ€™s
publisher and telling the presentation mode to dismiss.
Now letâ€™s go add this view to the navigation so we can truly use it.

button that the user would expect.

that will automagically handle forward and backwards navigation for us.
Then in the body, weâ€™ll need to reference that button to add it to the navigation bar. Youâ€™ll see a red
in the upper right hand corner of the app on the Home screen.
If you use this as it is, youâ€™ll notice that when you finish creating a new lean coffee, itâ€™s not displayed on this view. Letâ€™s fix that.

block on the
to refresh the page after that view dismisses.
In this section weâ€™ll add a
button to the Lean Coffee view and the form needed to create a new Topic
This is going to seem nearly identical to the last section, which means you could probably do a nice refactor on this when itâ€™s all said and done.
Again, weâ€™ll start with the presenter. This presenter will submit data to the API to create a Topic. Weâ€™ll make the encodable body object according to the
. If you look closely, we need to include the Lean Coffee ID in the request to the api, so weâ€™ll need to pass one into this presenter.
Make sure we inherit from the new FormSubmissionPresenter and override the form submission to make the call to the api.
Again, weâ€™ll add some really simple form validation to make sure that there is some text present before we submit the form.
Next, weâ€™ll create the view for this form. Weâ€™ll start with a stack and a title.
Then the text fields and the button.
And to acutally make the request, weâ€™ll pass in the presenter.
Then weâ€™ll add the presentation mode so we can dismiss this view when the work is done.
Now letâ€™s go add this view to the navigation so we can truly use it.

button as a
that will automagically handle forward and backwards navigation for us.
Then in the body, weâ€™ll need to reference that button to add it to the navigation bar. Youâ€™ll see a red
in the upper right hand corner of the app on the Home screen.
Finally, we can add an
block on the
to refresh the page after that view dismisses.
And that wraps up this tutorial seriesâ€¦
for now anyway.
There are many things we didnâ€™t cover, like handling accessible font sizes on small screens, screen readers, or testing. All of which would impact how the app was architected.
If youâ€™re intrested in learning more about those topics before I get back to this tutorial and add these topics, reach out to me (Jacob Rakidzich) on Teams.
